Award.AwardTitle: The medieval Black Death: analysis of the demographic, health, and social consequences of a historic emerging disease

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Sharon DeWitte (University of South Carolina) will investigate the Black Death (c. 1347-1351), a devastating disease that was caused by the pathogen responsible for modern bubonic plague. The Black Death was one of the most important emerging infectious diseases in history, and such diseases are still major threats to public health today. This three-year study will be done using the skeletal remains of people who died just before, during, and after the Black Death in London. It will address the questions of why the Black Death emerged when it did, how the selective mortality of the epidemic in combination with post-epidemic rising standards of living shaped health and demographic patterns within the surviving population, and how plague epidemiology changed over time.

This project will use hazard analysis of 1920 skeletons. Mortality and health patterns in the pre-Black Death period will reveal whether the population was becoming increasingly unhealthy before the epidemic. The post-Black Death samples will be analyzed to determine whether the surviving population faced lower risks of mortality, lived longer, and was healthier. This project will also reveal short-term changes in plague epidemiology that might have occurred because of changes in the human host or the pathogen.

This project is important because it will improve understanding of medieval plague and, more generally, emerging disease dynamics. Investigating these diseases is vital to understanding modern human biology, demography, and culture given their power to shape populations and drive human evolution. It is also important to understand the social, political, and economic processes that affect the emergence, epidemiology, and human experience of disease, and to expand the temporal scope of such inquiries. Assessment of emerging diseases in the past can also benefit efforts to prioritize funding for studying modern emerging diseases and for enacting surveillance and preventative measures in living populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Black Death killed millions of people in Asia, the Middle East, Africa, and Europe within just a few years during the 14th century. Because of the existence of rich documentary sources and well-dated cemetery collections from the medieval period, the Black Death provides an excellent model for understanding the social, economic, biological, and environmental conditions that give rise to deadly disease epidemics as well as the short- and long-term consequences of diseases in human populations. It is important to understand the behavior and effects of the Black Death because the 14th-century pandemic was caused by a bacterium (Yersinia pestis) that still causes disease and death in people today, and, more generally, we will continue to deal with existing and new diseases in the future. This project assessed over 2000 human skeletons from medieval London cemeteries dated to 1000-1540 AD to determine if and how health and demography changed in the period leading up to the Black Death and in the aftermath of the epidemic.

Hazards and survival analysis of individuals who died during two pre-Black Death periods (11th-12th centuries vs. 13th century) revealed that people were less likely to survive to later adult ages and risks of mortality increased in the 13th century compared to the 11th-12th centuries. Longevity and risk of mortality reflect underlying health conditions, so these results suggest that in the period leading up to the Black Death, general levels of health in London were worsening. This occurred at a time when climate changes were resulting in widespread and repeated famines and when there were growing social inequalities, including in access to food. This might have made the Black Death more deadly than it would have been had it struck a more robust or resilient population. Comparisons of people who died before the Black Death to those who died afterwards revealed substantial increases in the proportion of people who survived to old age and decreases in risks of mortality following the epidemic, which suggests that general levels of health were better after the Black Death than they had been before the epidemic. The results of analyses of skeletal stress markers, which form in response to things like nutritional deficiencies and disease, are consistent with the demographic patterns, further suggesting that people enjoyed better health at least for a few generations following the Black Death. These changes might have occurred because of improvements in standards of living, including better diets and decreased social inequalities in access to food. These changes might also reflect the deaths of large numbers of very frail individuals during the Black Death or alterations in human genetic variation with respect to immune competence or disease susceptibility that were driven by the epidemic. In addition to furthering our understanding of the emergence and consequences of the Black Death, this project promoted the use of hazards analysis in bioarchaeology and the integration of demographic and skeletal stress marker data in the reconstruction of variation in health and selective mortality in human populations; these approaches allow for more informative use of skeletal samples for the reconstruction of life in the past.

By supporting the training of graduate and undergraduate students, including a female first-generation college student, this project contributed to increasing diversity in STEM research. This project facilitated public outreach, as the results were presented in several talks that were open to the general public. Further, the results were presented at professional conferences and published in several peer-reviewed articles, one of which is open access and thus freely available to the general public. The results of this project have potential benefits to society, as revealing what makes people vulnerable to disease and death during epidemics can motivate us to take action, such as minimizing social inequalities, in order to reduce those vulnerabilities within living populations.
